Navassa Island map shows some features on this island in the Caribbean Sea.

media.alt: Astronaut photo of teardrop-shaped Navassa Island. The island is basically a plateau encircled by fairly steep cliffs. Image courtesy of NASA.
media.caption: Astronaut photo of teardrop-shaped Navassa Island. The island is basically a plateau encircled by fairly steep cliffs. Image courtesy of NASA.

media.alt: This aerial view of Navassa Island shows its flatness, cliff-lined shore, and scrubby vegetation. Image courtesy of the US Fish and Wildlife Service.
media.caption: This aerial view of Navassa Island shows its flatness, cliff-lined shore, and scrubby vegetation. Image courtesy of the US Fish and Wildlife Service.

media.alt: Navassa Island has a steep and rocky coastline that rings the island. Image courtesy USGS.
media.caption: Navassa Island has a steep and rocky coastline that rings the island. Image courtesy USGS.

media.alt: A shoreline view of Navassa Island from the top of the scrubby plateau looking out across the rocky beach to the sea. Image courtesy of the US Fish and Wildlife Service.
media.caption: A shoreline view of Navassa Island from the top of the scrubby plateau looking out across the rocky beach to the sea. Image courtesy of the US Fish and Wildlife Service.

media.alt: Navassa Island's lighthouse with the ruins of the light keeper's quarters in the foreground. Photo courtesy USGS.
media.caption: Navassa Island's lighthouse with the ruins of the light keeper's quarters in the foreground. Photo courtesy USGS.

media.alt: The ruins of Navassa Island's light keeper's quarters as seen from the lighthouse tower. Photo courtesy USGS.
media.caption: The ruins of Navassa Island's light keeper's quarters as seen from the lighthouse tower. Photo courtesy USGS.

fields.name: Background
fields.content: This uninhabited island was claimed by the US in 1857 for its guano. Mining took place between 1865 and 1898. The lighthouse, built in 1917, was shut down in 1996 and administration of Navassa Island transferred from the US Coast Guard to the Department of the Interior, Office of Insular Affairs. A 1998 scientific expedition to the island described it as a "unique preserve of Caribbean biodiversity." The following year it became a National Wildlife Refuge and annual scientific expeditions have continued.
fields.value: This uninhabited island was claimed by the US in 1857 for its guano. Mining took place between 1865 and 1898. The lighthouse, built in 1917, was shut down in 1996 and administration of Navassa Island transferred from the US Coast Guard to the Department of the Interior, Office of Insular Affairs. A 1998 scientific expedition to the island described it as a "unique preserve of Caribbean biodiversity." The following year it became a National Wildlife Refuge and annual scientific expeditions have continued.

fields.name: Terrain
fields.content: raised flat to undulating coral and limestone plateau; ringed by vertical white cliffs (9 to 15 m high)
fields.value: raised flat to undulating coral and limestone plateau; ringed by vertical white cliffs (9 to 15 m high)

fields.name: Geography - note
fields.content: strategic location 160 km south of the US Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba; mostly exposed rock with numerous solution holes (limestone sinkholes) but with enough grassland to support goat herds; dense stands of fig trees, scattered cactus
fields.value: strategic location 160 km south of the US Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba; mostly exposed rock with numerous solution holes (limestone sinkholes) but with enough grassland to support goat herds; dense stands of fig trees, scattered cactus

etymology: the flat island was named "Navaza" by some of Christopher COLUMBUS' sailors in 1504; the name derives from the Spanish term "nava" meaning "flat land, plain, or field"

fields.name: Dependency status
fields.content: unorganized, unincorporated territory of the US; administered by the Fish and Wildlife Service, US Department of the Interior from the Caribbean Islands National Wildlife Refuge in Boqueron, Puerto Rico; in September 1996, the Coast Guard ceased operations and maintenance of the Navassa Island Light, a 46-meter-tall lighthouse on the southern side of the island; Haiti has claimed the island since the 19th century
fields.value: unorganized, unincorporated territory of the US; administered by the Fish and Wildlife Service, US Department of the Interior from the Caribbean Islands National Wildlife Refuge in Boqueron, Puerto Rico; in September 1996, the Coast Guard ceased operations and maintenance of the Navassa Island Light, a 46-meter-tall lighthouse on the southern side of the island; Haiti has claimed the island since the 19th century

fields.name: Disputes - international
fields.content: Navassa Island (US)-Haiti: claimed by Haiti and is in Haiti’s constitution; the waters around Navassa island are a source of subsistence for Haitian fishermen
